column4: so to format an ntfs drive i figured i need to use gparted, but when i try to do so, there's an error claiming that that's an read-only filesystem
any help ?
you don't create the ntfs file system from linux
i need to format it
yes, you do that from windows
there is no windows option for me now
then why do you want an ntfs file system?
hard to explain at the moment but would be nice if i could just format it
is there any way to format ntfs hdd under ubuntu/linux ?
I don't know of any way to do that short of loading up windows.  since ntfs would be read only in linux, I can't imagine any reason to create an ntfs file system in linux.
but, regardless of whether there is a reason, as far as I know there is no way to do it.
so there is no way to format an ntfs filesystem under linux ?
i don't need to create one
just format it and for now that's the only reason ..
you are getting confused.  creating an ntfs partition, actually, you could do.  formatting it is windows bizarre terminology
in unix, you create a file system with mkfs.  windows incorrectly calls this "formatting"
now, you can create a partition, but you can't create an ntfs file system on that partition
so i should use mkfs and try to create, say fat32 ?
will it work ?
you can do mkfs.vfat, yes
I don't recommend that either, but as far as I know, it does work.
ok, thank you for now
will try to make something work, sigh, thanks again for your help
I think the odds are good that mkfs.vfat will work for you.
